citation.article-title: Leeia oryzae gen. nov., sp. nov., isolated from a rice field in Korea.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Leeia (Lee′i.a. N.L. fem. n. Leeia named after Keho Lee, a Korean microbiologist who devoted his life to the study of food micro-organisms).
Cells are Gram-negative, non-spore-forming short rods.
Cells are aerobic and are motile by means of single polar flagella.
The major isoprenoid quinone is Q-8.
Polar lipids are phosphatidylethanolamine, phosphatidylglycerol and diphosphatidylglycerol.
The predominant cellular fatty acids are C16 : 0 and summed feature 3 (C16 : 1ω7c and/or iso-C15 : 0 2-OH).
Phylogenetically, the genus belongs to the class Betaproteobacteria.
The type species is Leeia oryzae.
